item.question: What best describes “accessibility”?
item.choice: Accessibility is the degree to which a device is available to as many people as possible.
Accessibility is about making a device more easy to use.
Accessibility provides means to login on a computer system.
Accessibility is used to determine what you may or may not do on a computer system.
item.correct_answer: Accessibility is the degree to which a device is available to as many people as possible.
item.hint: Do not confuse accessibility with usability.

item.question:
On a system with a single network interface you are asked to make sure remotely logged in users are disconnected.
Which command would you use?
item.hint: The question does not tell you if running processes may be stopped as well. As you are assumed to be a good sysadmin you should pick the option that will minimize system disruption. Therefore, you should try to only disconnect the users and not bring down anything that can be kept running. To make it clear, shutting down is not considered a viable option nor switching to single user mode. Asking users politely to go away or killing them will probably not work.

item.question: Which of the following commands can be used to determine the MAC address of a network card installed in your laptop?
item.hint: Two of the commands are non-existing. The others both provide MAC address information. However, only one of them will show you which MAC address is associated with a specific network card.

item.question: Which of the following options for <font face="monospace">Xorg</font> will start the X server with a black background for the root window?
item.hint: Ok, <font face="monospace">b</font> stands for black, <font face="monospace">r</font> stands for root.

item.question: A user calls claiming that the internet is broken. What would you do first?
item.choice: Get your towel and don't panic.
Ask the user if he/she has tried turning the machine off and on again.
Logon to the user's machine to verify the claim.
Start explaining what the internet is, who invented it, and why it was invented.
item.correct_answer: Logon to the user's machine to verify the claim.
item.hint: Although many sysadmins would love to tell a user to simply turn the machine off and on again this is not considered a professional response. For more information see System Administrators' Code of Ethics. Explaining the user what the internet is might be very interesting for you and the user. However, this will not fix his/her problem.

item.question: When installing the X Window System the monitor was not correctly detected. Fortunately you found the technical specifications of the monitor. Which <font face="monospace">xorg.conf</font> section would you edit to specify the correct values for the monitor?
item.hint: <font face="monospace">Modeline</font> is used in <font face="monospace">xorg.conf</font> to provide information about a certain monitor and how to set it to a specified resolution. However it is not a section in the <font face="monospace">xorg.conf</font> file. The section <font face="monospace">Screen</font> specifies the default color depth and resolution you want to set the monitor too. However, it does not specify the technical aspects of the monitor like refresh rate and display size.

item.question: Which of the following is the default <font face="monospace">Xorg</font> configuration file?
item.hint: This one is actually pretty easy if you think about it. There is only one choice that specifies the configuration file under <font face="monospace">/etc</font>. Because you know that the default location for configuration files is under <font face="monospace">/etc</font> (according to the Filesystem Hierarchy Standard) your best bet would be that choice.

item.question: The __________ file maps TCP and UDP ports to service names.
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: Which of the following configuration files is used to configure access through XDMCP for remote X11 clients?
item.hint: In this case the hint is in the question ;)............ access.\nThe file xdm.conf is the main configuration file and usually specifies other files to hold specific configuration information. The Xsession is used by the program Xsession that will run as the user's session and setup the user's X environment. The file Xresources usually contains parameters for X widgets, such as color, size, etc.

item.question: What is the purpose of the file <font face="monospace">xdm-config</font> for <font face="monospace">xdm</font>? (Choose the best answer)
item.choice: Mostly referencing other configuration files for <font face="monospace">xdm</font>
It is a graphical tool to configure <font face="monospace">xdm</font>
item.correct_answer: Mostly referencing other configuration files for <font face="monospace">xdm</font>
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: Where is the queue directory for the CUPS system usually found? (provide the full directory-path)
item.hint: The default location for queues is under <font face="monospace">/var/spool</font>. In computer science, spool refers to the process of placing data in a temporary working area for another program to process. Each system that requires a spool creates its own directory under <font face="monospace">/var/spool</font>, usually named after the system that uses it.

item.question: Which of the following commands creates new log files and moves old ones?
item.hint: The method of moving old log files and possibly compressing them is called log rotation.

item.question: You get a complaint that domainname <font face="monospace">www.atcomputing.nl</font> cannot be reached. Which tool would be best to check if a router is causing problems?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: Which command can be used to add a new user on the server webserver?
item.hint: This question can be tricky if you do not know the answer directly. The reason is that it asks for adding a new user on a certain server. However, the server does not matter in this case. The question could just as easily be rephrased as follows: Which command can be used to add a new user?.

item.question: Which of the following websites are good resources for known security problems, and for obtaining patches and updates for vulnerable applications?
item.hint: Sorry, no hint for this one. You either know 'em or you don't.

item.question: Which of the following can you use to disable the system bell sound?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: Which utility can be used to restrict access to services managed by <font face="monospace">inetd</font>?
item.hint: The restriction mentioned in the question is network restriction through the TCP wrapper library. The service <font face="monospace">inetd</font> does not have support for TCP wrapper builtin. To enable access restriction using the TCP wrapper library <font face="monospace">inetd</font> can use a separate program to perform the check on behalf of <font face="monospace">inetd</font>.

item.question: You want syslog to sent all kernel messages with priority critical to all terminal-screens. Which of the following syslog configuration entries would you use?
item.hint: Most programs use the asterisk (<font face="monospace">*</font>) to specify all.

item.question: Consider the above exhibit. When the user logs in and starts a login shell what will be the value of the variable <font face="monospace">EDITOR</font>?
item.hint: All mentioned files in the exhibit are correct. You will need to know which files are read in which order when the user starts a login shell.

item.question: Considering below choices. What key combination can be used to force restarting the X server?
item.hint: Most Linux distributions running HAL have not enabled a key combination to restart the X server. Therefore, the correct answer may not even work on your system. However, in the past, all X servers would respond in the same manner to the key combination (<font face="monospace">xorg.conf</font> option <font face="monospace">DontZap</font>). The question is about those X servers and the key combination that would make them restart.

item.question: Which of the following are true? (Select all correct answers)
item.choice: Port 53 is used by the telnet service.
Port 143 is used by mail user agents to retrieve new mail.
Port 465 is used to provide encrypted HTTP traffic.
Port 25 is used by mail transfer agents to transport mail messages.
item.correct_answer: Port 143 is used by mail user agents to retrieve new mail.
Port 465 is used to provide encrypted HTTP traffic.
item.hint: LPI requires that you know the most common TCP and UDP ports. You can expect questions about portnumbers 20, 21, 22, 23, 25, 53, 80, 110, 119, 139, 143, 161, 443, 465, 993, 995.

item.question: Consider the above exhibit. When the user starts a non-login shell what will be the value of the variable <font face="monospace">EDITOR</font>?
item.hint: All mentioned files in the exhibit are correct. You will need to know which files are read in which order when the user starts a non-login shell.

item.question: Which configuration file would you edit to change the default options for ssh sessions to other machines?
item.hint: When a command name ends at the letter <font face="monospace">d</font> it usually refers to daemon. Therefore, <font face="monospace">sshd</font> refers to the daemon of the ssh service. The client program has the same name but without the <font face="monospace">d</font> at the end.

item.question: You have generated a DSA authentication key on host linux1. In order to log into host linux2 with the new key, what would you need to do?
item.choice: Log into linux2 using the command ssh-key.
Copy the new authentication key into $HOME/.ssh/id_dsa on linux2.
Copy the new authentication key into $HOME/.ssh/authorized_keys on linux2.
Copy the new authentication key into $HOME/.ssh/id_dsa on linux1.
Copy the new authentication key into /etc/ssh/sshd_config on linux2.
item.correct_answer: Copy the new authentication key into $HOME/.ssh/authorized_keys on linux2.
item.hint: The question is about making public key authentication possible for a user. You may assume $HOME points to the correct user's homedirectory. To enable public key authentication you will need to add the public key from linux1 to the ssh configuration for the user on linux2. If DSA is used the private key is named id_dsa by default, and the public key id_dsa.pub. The latter needs to be copied to the correct file on linux2.

item.question:
Your company policy does not allow anything but ssh as a remote login service.
During your monthly security audit you discover that one of your machines provides remote login services
on port 23. What would you do?
item.choice: Deactivate it, you dont need a SMTP server there.
Deactivate it, you should not use <font face="monospace">telnet</font>.
Nothing, this is ok as <font face="monospace">ssh</font> is a safe login service.
Setup a firewall on the machine to block traffic to port 23.
item.correct_answer: Deactivate it, you should not use <font face="monospace">telnet</font>.
item.hint: LPI requires that you know the most common TCP and UDP ports. You can expect questions about portnumbers 20, 21, 22, 23, 25, 53, 80, 110, 119, 139, 143, 161, 443, 465, 993, 995. The service <font face="monospace">ssh</font> uses port number 22 which is considered secure. Port 23 is normally used for an insecure login service and should not be used.

item.question: Which of the following statements best describes the output in above exhibit.
item.choice: All sources will be inquired once every 64 seconds.
The system will synchronize with <font face="monospace">ams1.x31.com</font> or <font face="monospace">243-51-223.ftth</font> or <font face="monospace">ntp0.mediamatic</font>.
The system clock is running slow.
The system will synchronize with <font face="monospace">sip.dicode.nl</font> or <font face="monospace">europium.canoni</font>.
item.correct_answer: All sources will be inquired once every 64 seconds.
The system clock is running slow.
item.hint: With <font face="monospace">ntpq</font> you can see which remote timeservers are used as time synchronization sources. The character at the beginning of each line specifies the status of the candidate. A <font face="monospace">*</font> means it is used as the system peer and it is used as the time synchronization source. A <font face="monospace">+</font> means it is a possible candidate. A <font face="monospace">-</font> means it has been discarded as a possible time synchronization source. The column poll shows the interval in seconds at which the time source is polled. The offset shows the difference between the local time and the remote time. A positive offset means the local time is running behind.

item.question: Your senior system administrator asked you to edit the <font face="monospace">/etc/inetd.conf</font> file in order to disable the time service. After doing so, what would be the next thing to do?
item.choice: Find the PID of <font face="monospace">inetd</font> and send it a <font face="monospace">SIGHUP</font>.
Find the PID of <font face="monospace">inetd</font> and kill it with <font face="monospace">kill -15</font>.
item.correct_answer: Find the PID of <font face="monospace">inetd</font> and send it a <font face="monospace">SIGHUP</font>.
item.hint: Many daemons interpret the hangup signal as restarting and/or reloading the configuration file.

item.question: The ________ file is the configuration file for <font face="monospace">ntpd</font>.
item.hint: The question does not state explicitly if you should include the path as well. Therefore, you may assume it does not matter and both are considered correct.

item.question: Which of the following services are usually NOT protected via TCP wrappers?
item.hint: Some programs have builtin support for TCP wrappers, others are protected as they are started by <font face="monospace">inetd</font> or <font face="monospace">xinetd</font>. Some don't use TCP wrappers at all and have their own methods for access control. The Apache webserver is never started by <font face="monospace">inetd</font> or <font face="monospace">xinetd</font>.

item.question: Which of the following IP networks does RFC 1918 reserve for use on private intranets?
item.hint: There are three such ranges. One is <font face="monospace">192.168.0.0/24</font> and another is <font face="monospace">172.16.0.0/12</font>. The third range is contains one of the ip adresses in the given choices.

item.question: You want to convert the text-file <font face="monospace">guru.txt</font> to postscript to have it printed out later on. Which of the following commandlines would you use to accomplish this?
item.hint: Note that the question mentions you will be printing later on. Therefore, the correct answer only converts the file and does not print it as well.

item.question: A user calls and complains that he/she cannot work with the text-editor that is started when he/she wants to write an email using a text-oriented mailprogram like <font face="monospace">mutt</font> or <font face="monospace">pine</font>. Which file is best to edit to define a different default text-editor?
item.hint: The skel directory is only effective for new users. The question is about changing the pager for an existing user and only a single user. Therefore, it boils down to knowing the difference between <font face="monospace">.bashrc</font> and <font face="monospace">.bash_profile</font>.

item.question: You just started your new job as sysadmin and stumble upon a system that still uses passwords in <font face="monospace">/etc/passwd</font>. Which of the following tools allows you to convert the password system to the “shadowed password file”?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: Which of the following files are used by a linux system for name to ip-address translations? (Select TWO answers.)
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: Which of the following are mail transfer agents?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: If you want to execute a script called <font face="monospace">findguru</font> and want to disable the variable <font face="monospace">GURU</font> only for the current execution of the script, which of the following commandlines is correct?
item.hint: To setup the environment for a program you use the command <font face="monospace">env</font>.

item.question: Which command will delete the environment variable <font face="monospace">EDITOR</font>?
item.hint: Redefining a variable with empty input will not remove the variable. Although most of the time the difference is not noticeable when the option <font face="monospace">-u</font> is set for Bash unset variables will invoke an error when they are expanded. Expansion is requested when you precede the variable name with a <font face="monospace">$</font>. Whenever you want to manipulate the actual variable you should use the variable name without preceding it with a <font face="monospace">$</font>.

item.question: What is the configuration file for the syslog daemon? Give both the path and the filename.
item.hint: There are multiple questions about syslog. Especially the multiple choice questions can come in handy as they may provide you with the exact answer to this question.

item.question: In order to bypass print filters using lpr, which of following switches should be used:
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: Which of the following commands allows you to print the file <font face="monospace">linux.txt</font> and delete the file afterwards?
item.hint: Most linux commands try to make the options self explaining as much as possible. Thus, deletion is usually connected to an option <font face="monospace">-r</font> or <font face="monospace">-d</font>. Now you got a 50/50 chance of guessing the right answer. Although the <font face="monospace">--remove</font> might get you out of balance.

item.question:
Which of the following would execute the script updaterepository twice per hour between 20:00 and 06:00 hours
on monday to friday?
item.hint: The format for a system crontab entry is: minutes, hours, day of month, month, day of week, user, command.

item.question: You execute the command <font face="monospace">date +%M</font>. What will the output show you?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: Which of the following tools is best to copy a file over a network in a secure manner?
item.hint: We are looking for a “secure copy” mechanism.

item.question: What file is used to display messages at the login prompt when users log in remotely using <font face="monospace">telnet</font>?
item.hint: As good sysadmin you probably disabled <font face="monospace">telnet</font> on all your systems and will never have use for the asked file. However, you do probably know the local version that is used to display a text message before the login prompt on a console login screen. This file also has a network version that is used when a login screen is presented over a network, for instance when using <font face="monospace">telnet</font>.

item.question: You use above <font face="monospace">enscript</font> command regularly to print out a nice formatted version of your scripts. How can you convert above command easily into a single word command and still allows you to specify one or more filenames as command line arguments?
item.choice: Download the source code for <font face="monospace">enscript</font>, modify it to make my options default, compile and install it.
Post a bug report asking the developers to make my options the default.
item.hint: The question is about an easy way.

item.question: You just migrated your DNS server to a new machine and now need to update the clients to use the new DNS server. Which file do you need to change?
item.hint: The C library many programs use contains routines that provide access to DNS. This set of routines is called the resolver.

item.question: Which of the following lines from <font face="monospace">/etc/X11/xorg.conf</font> indicates a font server must be used?
item.hint: A font server is accessed through a communication service such as an IP network or Unix domain sockets. When you access a font server through a domain socket you need to specify <font face="monospace">unix</font> with the correct port number.

item.question: Which two daemons will start services on demand?
item.hint: This question is about the concept of a super daemon. This is a daemon that will listen to network connections on behalf of other daemons. Whenever a connection is made the corresponding daemon is started by the super daemon to handle the network session. The benefit is that you only need one daemon running at all times and the super daemon can connect standard input and output to the network. The latter allows you to write a simple shell script as a network daemon.

item.question: What can you do to recover a lost passphrase for a DSA or RSA authentication key?
item.choice: Decrypt the authentication key with gpg.
A lost passphrase cannot be recovered.
Use a brute force method to guess the correct passphrase
item.correct_answer: Use a brute force method to guess the correct passphrase
item.hint: A lost passphrase for a DSA or RSA key cannot be retrieved using somekind of decryption technique. You can however use a cryptanalysis method to try to guess the lost passphrase. If this will be succesful during your lifetime depends on the chosen passphrase and its complexity.

item.question: What is the purpose of the <font face="monospace">export</font> command?
item.choice: To save the history file to a compatible format to be used by other shells.
To run a command in the current shell instead of a child-shell.
To setup environment variables for applications started in the shell.
item.correct_answer: To setup environment variables for applications started in the shell.
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: Using <font face="monospace">xdm</font> users may create and edit a configuration file in their home directory that can tell the X window system what window manager they wish to start when they log in. Which file is that?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question:
Consider the following partial output from a linux system configuration file.
Which of the following files includes above output?
item.hint: The file shows service names with their associated portnumbers as assigned by IANA.

item.question: You need to investigate which machine on your network fails to forward IP packets. Which command will be best to locate the machine?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: You are running an IPv6 network and a system on that network needs to sent a packet to another IPv4 only system with IPv4 address <font face="monospace">80.113.6.236</font>. Provide the IPv4 mapped IPv6 address.
item.hint: There are many ways to provide the asked address. However, you should provide the answer with the minimal amount of characters possible. Hence, reduce as much zero's as possible by <font face="monospace">::</font>.

item.question: Which of the following protocols uses different network ports for data control and data transfer?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: What best describes above statement?
item.choice: It will give an error as you can only select from one table at a time.

SELECT will delete all rows in the tables books and authors where
the id column in books matches the book_id column.
It will return only the columns <font face="monospace">title</font> and <font face="monospace">name</font> in the result.

It will select usage of the title and name on tables books and authors if and
only if the id equals book_id.
item.correct_answer: It will return only the columns <font face="monospace">title</font> and <font face="monospace">name</font> in the result.
item.hint: The statement comes from SQL. The SELECT will return rows FROM one or more tables using WHERE as a criterium.

item.question:
Consider the above syslog priorities.
Which represents the highest priority?
Select all correct answers.
item.hint: Some priorities have multiple names. Usually a short abbreviated version and a long version.

item.question: To let your NTP service synchronize with an external source you would modify the file?
item.hint: Most programs that use a configuration file under <font face="monospace">/etc</font> create a new directory usually naming it after the program. However, <font face="monospace">ntp</font> does not and places its configuration file directly under <font face="monospace">/etc</font>.

item.question: Your company policy requires employees to change their password once every 6 months and demands that a user-account will be disabled if the user fails to change her password within a grace period of 30 days. How would you accomplish this?
item.hint: To manipulate password ageing information the file <font face="monospace">/etc/shadow</font> must be edited. Although you can do this using a normal text-editor it is wise to use a dedicated command for this.

item.question:
Consider the following command:
What will be the result?
item.choice: The primary bash prompt includes the username and hostname
The primary bash prompt includes the current working directory and hostname
The secondary bash prompt includes the username and hostname
The secondary bash prompt includes the username and full hostname
item.correct_answer: The primary bash prompt includes the username and hostname
item.hint: The macro's used by the shell usually use the first letter of the spelled out name.
